Starting today, the types of furniture most at risk for tip-overs will be subject to mandatory safety standards and will have to undergo rigorous safety testing before being sold, helping reduce the likelihood of tip overs & resulting injuries.

Too many families have faced unimaginable tragedy because inadequate furniture safety standards have left furniture at risk of tipping over.  Tip-over accidents cause roughly 22,500 emergency room-related injuries & even worse - hundreds of parents have lost children as a result.

NEWS: Today, my STURDY Act goes into effect. No parent should have to worry about unsafe furniture putting their children at risk. That’s why I fought to get this passed.

"For me, my disability is not a curse. It’s not a handicap. It is a gift so that I can help implement change.” 

Shawn Aleong, a fierce advocate for people with disabilities, is our third honoree and embodies the steadfast grit and persistence found in many Pennsylvanians.

Our first honoree is Hettie Simmons Love from Harrisburg. The first African American to earn an MBA from @Wharton, she has spent her life donating time and talent to others, serving as a leader in her community and an inspiration to generations to come.

#BetterCareBetterJobs is not just the right thing to do, it's also a smart economic investment. This bill will boost our economy by creating good-paying jobs and allowing more people to reenter the workforce.

The #BetterCareBetterJobs Act will allow seniors and people with disabilities receive care in their homes and communities, while also increasing pay and improving benefits for the caregivers who provide this life-sustaining care.

Today, @RepDebDingell and I are introducing the #BetterCareBetterJobs Act to make a generational investment in home care. 

For too long, many families thought this was a personal issue that they had to deal with on their own.  But they are not alone in this fight.

The United States in the midst of a caregiving crisis. 

Across this Nation, seniors and people with disabilities are struggling to find and afford care, forcing families to make difficult decisions like leaving the workforce in order to care for a loved one.

On this second anniversary, we must remain vigilant against extremism, demand accountability for those responsible for the January 6 attack, and reject anti-democratic values from political leaders.
Though former President Trump failed that day, his legacy lives on as members of the Republican Party embraced his Big Lie and continue to sow doubt in our elections and democratic institutions.

In the two years since, hundreds of insurrectionists have been charged for their crimes and, through the work of the January 6th Committee, we have seen just how far the former President and his supporters were willing to go to destroy our Democracy.

I am forever grateful for the law enforcement officers who put their lives on the line to defend the Capitol. Without their bravery and sacrifice, it’s hard to imagine the additional horrors our Nation may have seen that day.
Two years ago, at the encouragement of the former President, a violent mob stormed the Capitol, attacked law enforcement officers, and tried to stop democracy in its tracks.

In the coming months I will undergo surgery, after which I am expected to make a full recovery. I am confident that my recommended course of treatment will allow me to continue my service in the 118th Congress with minimal disruption, and I look forward to the work ahead.

Last month, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. While this news came as a shock, I can report that I have an excellent prognosis, as well as the benefit of exceptional medical care and the unwavering support of my family.
